Will, i doubt youll see this, but I want to give you correct information regarding emotional processing.  When you say "Im trying not to be ashamed of myself, but rather deeply remoresful" - this is not the correct psychological route to take. Youve likely been advised that shame is bad, toxic, etc. That is wrong - it is REPRESSED or INTERNALIZED shame that is harmful.  Instead, in a situation like this, you need to allow that shame to be FELT. In a situation like this, shame is the natural emotion to come up. You need to hold space for that feeling. It is very painful. It also is HUMBLING. After you face the feelings of shame, sit with them, you will feel completely humbled, but there will be a RELIEF that floods you. You will no longer be resisting your own emotions. Youll no longer be fighting them. And you will be so much wiser as a result.  Remorse is also necessary, but it is repressed shame which our culture does not properly deal with, and many stuggle due tp that fact. With your influence, if you deal with this properly and allow yourself to be vulnerable, you could really make a huge impact in the world.

Coney Island Chili Dogs  Ingredients:  - 1 1/2 pounds lean ground beef - 2 cups of water - 3/4 cup diced onion - 1/3 cup ketchup - 2 tablespoons butter - 2 cloves garlic - 2 tablespoons chili powder - 1 1/2 teaspoons salt - 1 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper - 1 teaspoon ground cumin - 1/2 teaspoon celery salt - 1 pinch cayenne pepper - 8 all-beef hot dogs  - 8 hot dog buns - 1/4 cup prepared yellow mustard  Directions:  1. Combine ground beef, water, 1/2 cup diced onion, ketchup, butter, garlic, chili powder, salt, black pepper, cumin, celery salt, and cayenne pepper together in a pot. Mix with a potato masher or spatula over medium-high heat until mixture has a finely ground consistency and begins to bubble, about 10 minutes. 2. Bring beef mixture to a simmer, reduce heat to medium-low, and cook, stirring occasionally, until sauce thickens and reduces, about 1 hour. Season with salt and pepper to taste. 3. Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Cook hot dogs in boiling water until heated through, 5 to 7 minutes. 4. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Arrange hot dog buns on a baking sheet. 5. Cook buns in the preheated oven until soft and warm, 2 to 3 minutes. 6. Place 1 bun on a plate. Place a hot dog in the bun and top with meat sauce. Drizzle yellow mustard and a portion of remaining diced onion over the meat sauce. Repeat with remaining hot dogs.

MS-DOS acronym for Microsoft Disk Operating System, also known as Microsoft DOS) is an operating system for x86-based personal computers mostly developed by Microsoft. Collectively, MS-DOS, its rebranding as IBM PC DOS, and a few operating systems attempting to be compatible with MS-DOS, are sometimes referred to as "DOS" (which is also the generic acronym for disk operating system). MS-DOS was the main operating system for IBM PC compatibles during the 1980s, from which point it was gradually superseded by operating systems offering a graphical user interface (GUI), in various generations of the graphical Microsoft Windows operating system.   IBM licensed and re-released it in 1981 as PC DOS 1.0 for use in its PCs. Although MS-DOS and PC DOS were initially developed in parallel by Microsoft and IBM, the two products diverged after twelve years, in 1993.   Ultimately, it was the key product in Microsoft's development from a programming language company to a diverse software development firm, providing the company with essential revenue and marketing resources. It was also the underlying basic operating system on which early versions of Windows ran as a GUI.

Anger Management:  1. Think before you speak   In the heat of the moment, it's easy to say something you'll later regret. Take a few moments to collect your thoughts before saying anything. Also allow others involved in the situation to do the same.    2. Once you're calm, express your concerns  As soon as you're thinking clearly, express your frustration in an assertive but nonconfrontational way. State your concerns and needs clearly and directly, without hurting others or trying to control them.    3. Get some exercise  Physical activity can help reduce stress that can cause you to become angry. If you feel your anger escalating, go for a brisk walk or run. Or spend some time doing other enjoyable physical activities.    4. Take a timeout  Timeouts aren't just for kids. Give yourself short breaks during times of the day that tend to be stressful. A few moments of quiet time might help you feel better prepared to handle what's ahead without getting irritated or angry. 5. Identify possible solutions  Instead of focusing on what made you mad, work on resolving the issue at hand. Does your child's messy room make you upset? Close the door. Is your partner late for dinner every night? Schedule meals later in the evening. Or agree to eat on your own a few times a week. Also, understand that some things are simply out of your control. Try to be realistic about what you can and cannot change. Remind yourself that anger won't fix anything and might only make it worse. 6. Stick with 'I' statements  Criticizing or placing blame might only increase tension. Instead, use "I" statements to describe the problem. Be respectful and specific. For example, say, "I'm upset that you left the table without offering to help with the dishes" instead of "You never do any housework."    7. Don't hold a grudge  Forgiveness is a powerful tool. If you allow anger and other negative feelings to crowd out positive feelings, you might find yourself swallowed up by your own bitterness or sense of injustice. Forgiving someone who angered you might help you both learn from the situation and strengthen your relationship.    8. Use humor to release tension  Lightening up can help diffuse tension. Use humor to help you face what's making you angry and, possibly, any unrealistic expectations you have for how things should go. Avoid sarcasm, though â€” it can hurt feelings and make things worse.    9. Practice relaxation skills  When your temper flares, put relaxation skills to work. Practice deep-breathing exercises, imagine a relaxing scene, or repeat a calming word or phrase, such as "Take it easy." You might also listen to music, write in a journal or do a few yoga poses â€” whatever it takes to encourage relaxation.    10. Know when to seek help  Learning to control anger can be a challenge at times. Seek help for anger issues if your anger seems out of control, causes you to do things you regret or hurts those around you.

"Trying to be remorseful without feeling like a piece of ğŸ’©" is the difference between an #apology and a #sorry...  An apology is just an explanation,  acknowledgement and onus of what happened... The etymology of the word apology is Greek apologia meaning a "defence, story, justification, account". So just because someone apologises doesn't mean they feel/are sorry... Sorry is an old English word meaning to be "grieved, feel SORROW". 'Sorry' comes from 'sorrow' ; you can't be sorry without feeling sorrow (like ğŸ’©)... When someone is sorry they actually HAVE TO #FEEL bad (like a piece ğŸ’©) and remorseful. ğŸ¤·ğŸ¾â€â™‚ï¸  *An apology is NOT a **#feeling**, sorry and remorse ARE.*  Trying NOT to feel bad "like ğŸ’©" whilst simultaneously trying to be remorseful is like trying to swim and not get (feel) wet... it's a Sisyphean contradicting paradox. #impossible   Mr William's speech comes off more as an a apology trying to be a sorry... Remorse and sorrow aren't emotions you TRY to have/be; you either are sorry and own the feeling of being a piece of ğŸ’©  OR you give people an apology (account, defense, story).

Researcher Aaron Lazare studied apologies for years, and concluded that an effective apology has four parts:   1. It acknowledges the offense (who did the harm to whom, and exactly what the harm was),  2. offers an explanation for the offense (not an excuse, but an explanation),  3. expresses remorse or shame (some recognition of the depth of suffering caused is needed here), and  4. involves a repair of some kind (compensation, in a real or symbolic way, for the offenderâ€™s transgression)  it seems several of these elements are missing here. wdyt?

Apology is the expression of regret or remorse for an offense or injury. Forgiveness is the pardon for something that has been done. This is the key difference between apology and forgiveness. Making apologies and granting forgiveness are vital aspects in any type of relationship, even the one you had with Chris. It is a thing that goes both ways. Apologize - this shows that you understand what you've done, and then ask for forgiveness from the person. One of the things here is also trying to forgive yourself, learn from it and rise above it. Actions speak louder than any words. Be yourself, do what you believe is right and do it sincerily. This is how you should show the world that you're "putting light and love and joy into the world." I think the hardest lesson to be learned, quite possibly, is that some things really can't be fixed. I believe Will Smith is genuinely sorry...and it's great to see him take that responsibility to TRY and fix the situation...but ultimately, there may not be a way to return to the way things were before. Chris may not be willing to forgive him. The fans and the public may not be willing to fully forgive and support Will Smith. His family and their reputation/image may be forever sullied by the incident and the fallout. Things may be permanently damaged. While forgiveness may be "divine", the world is made up of humans with feelings and while they may not necessarily continue to villainize people for their actions that doesn't mean things go "back to normal".  The apology and contrition may be there...and that's wonderful. The key question is...can Will Smith remain humble in the face of a permanent loss? It certainly can be an opportunity to start rebuilding...but can Will Smith live with the possibility that this may be, forever, a regret? This is one of the hardest lessons for a person to learn...and one that's very difficult because everyone believes that they can fix things...but some things really do break and that is a hard, hard thing...and one that I hope everyone understands that is at stake here. There is a weight to bear...and it shouldn't be about "moving past" it...it should be about "moving on with it". Understand that, to a degree, this action DOES define you...and that can be used as a restraint (holding you back), a crutch (holding you up), a ladder (raising you up), or a platform (raising your voice)...which one of these will it be for Will Smith?

Here's a thought. Ask for forgiveness. Say, "I am so sorry, will you please forgive me?" Asking for forgiveness creates a genuine opportunity for reconciliation, and establishes a two way dialogue between the offender and the offended. Asking forgiveness is very difficult. You will be humbled and vulnerable but, it is the most genuine and sincere way to apologize to someone. It provides the offended an opportunity, a choice, to actively participate in the apology and respond to your request for forgiveness. The offended party might not respond right away, but if they choose to never respond, it's on them now. You've sincerely done all you can do to reconcile and begin to heal the hurts.
